questions.text: A 13-year-old boy comes to the clinic due to shortness of breath and fatigue over the past 2 weeks. He reports significant weight gain, swelling around the ankles, and profound fatigue. Laboratory findings include red blood cell casts in urine and elevated creatinine. Immunofluorescence microscopy shown. Which of the following light microscopy findings is most likely to be seen in this patient’s renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crescent formation

 

  • The patient's presentation of shortness of breath, fatigue, weight gain, peripheral edema, red blood cell casts in the urine, and elevated creatinine suggests rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). 
  • The key diagnostic feature here is red blood cell casts, which point toward glomerular inflammation.
  • The immunofluorescence microscopy image (not shown here but stated in the query) likely indicates the type of immune deposits.
  • Answer choice B, crescent formation, refers to a severe glomerular injury pattern seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
  • Crescents form due to proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltration of inflammatory cells in Bowman's space following severe glomerular basement membrane rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subepithelial deposits: Are characteristic of membranous nephropathy, which typically causes nephrotic syndrome without red blood cell casts or rapidly progressive symptoms.

 

Option C. Nodular glomerulosclerosis: Is characteristic of diabetic nephropathy.

 

Option D. Normal glomeruli: Would not explain the clinical and laboratory findings. Thus, the most likely light microscopy finding is crescent formation, consistent with RPGN, matching the clinical picture of acute renal injury with active urinary sediment (red blood cell casts) and immunofluorescence findings suggesting immune-mediated injury.

 

Educational Objectives: 

 

  • In summary, the clinical, laboratory, and microscopy findings are consistent with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis characterized by crescent formation on light microscopy.

questions.text:
Which of the following is most likely based on the lab values given?

 

Blood pH: 7.3

Na+: 134 mEq/L

K+: 2.8 mEq/L

Cl: 113mEq/L

HCO3-: 12mEq/L

BUN: 3 mg/dL

Creatinine: 0.6mg/dL

Urinary pH: 4.4
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type 2 RTA

 

Based on the lab values given:

 

  • Blood pH: 7.3 (mild acidemia)
  • Na+: 134 mEq/L (normal to slightly low)
  • K+: 2.8 mEq/L (hypokalemia)
  • Cl: 113 mEq/L (elevated)
  • HCO3-: 12 mEq/L (low)
  • BUN and Creatinine normal (no kidney failure)
  • Urine pH: 4.4 (acidic urine)

 

The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis with low bicarbonate, hypokalemia, and acidic urine (pH < 5.5). Elevated chloride (hyperchloremic) suggests a metabolic acidosis due to bicarbonate loss or impaired acid excretion.

 

Reviewing types of renal tubular acidosis (RTA):

 

  • Type 1 (distal) RTA: impaired distal acid secretion; urine pH remains >5.5 despite systemic acidosis; hypokalemia; metabolic acidosis.
  • Type 2 (proximal) RTA: impaired proximal bicarbonate reabsorption; urine pH initially >7, but can fall below 5.5 once bicarbonate depleted; hypokalemia; metabolic acidosis.
  • Type 4 RTA: hypoaldosteronism; hyperkalemia; metabolic acidosis; urine pH usually <5.5.

 

2  1  4 = LOW LOW MORE

 

The patient’s low potassium (2.8 mEq/L) excludes type 4 RTA, which involves hyperkalemia. The acidic urine pH (4.4) supports distal nephron acidification. Low bicarbonate and hypokalemia fit type 1 (distal) RTA.

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is excluded because the patient has hyperchloremic (normal anion gap) metabolic acidosis with no evidence of elevated BUN or creatinine.

 

Therefore, the most likely diagnosis based on lab values is:

 

B) Type 1 Renal Tubular Acidosis (distal RTA)

 

This matches with hypokalemia, low bicarbonate, acidic urine, and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Decreased renal perfusion, decreased intraglomerular pressure, and constant filtration fraction
Increased renal perfusion, decreased intraglomerular pressure, and decreased filtration fraction
Decreased renal perfusion, increased intraglomerular pressure, and decreased filtration fraction
Decreased renal perfusion, decreased intraglomerular pressure, and reduced filtration fraction

questions.text: Which of the following changes are most likely to occur in this patient’s kidney function after starting therapy with NSAID?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased renal perfusion, decreased intraglomerular pressure, and constant filtration fraction

 

  • NSAIDs primarily block the production of renal prostaglandins, which normally dilate the afferent arteriole of the glomerulus to maintain renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate (GFR), especially in states of decreased effective circulating volume.

 

Effect of NSAIDs on kidney function:

 

  • They cause afferent arteriole vasoconstriction, leading to decreased renal perfusion.
  • This decreases both glomerular hydrostatic pressure (intraglomerular pressure) and GFR.
  • Since renal plasma flow (RPF) decreases along with GFR, the filtration fraction (FF = GFR/RPF) often remains constant.
  • Summarizing these effects, the most accurate description after starting   

NSAIDs is:

 

Decreased renal perfusion, decreased intraglomerular pressure, and constant filtration fraction

 

This corresponds to afferent arteriole constriction without disproportionate changes in efferent arteriole tone, resulting in parallel decreases in RPF and GFR, thus keeping the filtration fraction relatively stable

questions.text: Low Renin Hypertension is seen in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liddle syndrome

 

  • Low renin hypertension is characterized by hypertension with low or suppressed plasma renin levels.
  • Liddle syndrome is a genetic form of hypertension caused by gain-of-function mutations in the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC), leading to increased sodium reabsorption independent of aldosterone, resulting in hypertension with low renin and low aldosterone levels.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Reninoma (juxtaglomerular cell tumor): Causes renin-secreting tumor leading to high renin and secondary hypertension.

 

Option C. Renovascular hypertension (e.g., renal artery stenosis): Results from decreased renal perfusion causing high renin secretion.

 

Option D. Fibromuscular dysplasia: Is a cause of renovascular hypertension and typically presents with high renin levels due to arterial stenosis and compensatory renin secretion.

 

Educational Objectives: 

 

Therefore, the condition associated with low renin hypertension among the options is: Liddle syndrome

questions.text: A patient has a blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30 mg/min

 

The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

 

Calculation:

 

Step 1: Total filtered glucose calculated by GFR x Plasma glucose concentration

 

Here,

 

  • ﻿﻿GFR = 90 ml/min
  • ﻿﻿Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • ﻿﻿Total filtered glucose = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml = 180 mg/min.

 

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

 

Here, as shown in the graph transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

 

Step 3: Calculate the excretion

 

  • Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)
  • As calculated above, total filtered glucose is 180, Transport maximum is 150
  • = 180-150 mg/min = 30 mg/min is the excretion

 

Educational Objective 

 

Total filtered glucose=GFR × Plasma glucose concentration

Excretion=Total filtered glucose−Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Max.)

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycationic, Neutral, polyanionic 

 

Based on the given graph, that A has the highest filterability, followed by B and C, it is likely that A has a smaller size and/or a positive charge, making it easier to pass through the filtration membrane. Similarly, C is likely larger and/or negatively charged, leading to reduced filterability. Therefore, the answer would be: Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic.

 

Negatively charged glomerular filtration barrier is responsible for the differential filtration of charged substances. The order of filterability observed in the graph suggests that A is polycationic, B is neutral, and C is polyanionic. This is because polycationic substances would be readily filtered due to their positive charge, while polyanionic substances would be repelled by the negatively charged barrier and exhibit low filterability. Neutral substances would fall somewhere in between, depending on their size and shape. The molecular size exclusion limit you mentioned (between 4-8 nm) is also important for determining which substances are able to be filtered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filterability of substances through the kidney glomerular filtration barrier depends on their charge and size. Polycationic substances (positively charged) filter most readily, neutral substances have intermediate filterability, and polyanionic substances (negatively charged) have the least filterability due to repulsion by the negatively charged barrier.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the OPD with several months of vision problems, difficulty chewing, and trouble speaking. The symptoms fluctuate, but the patient has noticed that they are worse after a long day. During physical examination, the patient is asked to keep her eyes focused on a spot on the ceiling, and after 2 minutes she develops diplopia. The pathogenesis of this patient's disease is most similar to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goodpasture syndrome 

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is caused by autoantibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction.
  • This is a type II hypersensitivity reaction → antibodies directed against cell-surface receptors.
  • Goodpasture syndrome is also a type II hypersensitivity disorder, where antibodies target the basement membrane in lungs and kidneys.
    Hence, both share the same pathogenesis (antibody-mediated cell surface damage).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atopic dermatitis: Type I hypersensitivity (IgE-mediated, mast cell degranulation). 

 

Option B. Contact dermatitis: Type IV hypersensitivity (T-cell mediated, delayed). 

 

Option D. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: Type III hypersensitivity (immune complex mediated).

choices.text: Indomethacin may be used for treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Bartter's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autosomal dominant disorder 

 

  • True statements:
    • A. Hypokalaemia and metabolic alkalosis: due to increased distal sodium delivery → enhanced K⁺ and H⁺ secretion.
    • B. Indomethacin may be used for treatment: because excess renal prostaglandins worsen salt wasting → NSAIDs help.
    • C. Associated with sensorineural deafness: especially in Bartter type IV (BSND gene mutation).

 

  • False statement:
    • D. Autosomal dominant disorder → Most forms of Bartter’s syndrome are autosomal recessive.

questions.text: Where in the tubule would a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Stepwise Reasoning

 

  1. Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI):
    • ADH is absent.
    • Collecting ducts become impermeable to water.
    • No water reabsorption occurs in collecting ducts.
    • Urine becomes maximally dilute (hypo-osmotic).
  2. Tubular fluid osmolality along nephron in DI:
    • Proximal tubule (A): isotonic (~300 mOsm/L).
    • Descending limb: hypertonic (water leaves, solutes retained).
    • Ascending limb (B, C): impermeable to water, NaCl reabsorbed → tubular fluid becomes progressively hypotonic (~100 mOsm/L).
    • Collecting duct (D):
      • Normally, ADH makes it permeable → water reabsorbed, urine concentrated.
      • In central DI, no ADH → remains impermeable → tubular fluid becomes even more dilute (as low as 50–70 mOsm/L).
  3. Lowest osmolality site:
    → Collecting duct (D) in the absence of ADH.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with 400 ml urine output in 24 hours. On biopsy he had crescents with pauci immune glomerulonephritis. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ANCA

 

ANCA  → most appropriate next test because pauci-immune GN is strongly linked to ANCA-associated vasculitis

 

Clinical scenario

 

  • 47-year-old male
  • Severe oliguria (urine output 400 mL/24h) → suggests rapidly progressive renal failure.
  • Biopsy finding: crescents with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

 

Interpretation

 

  1. Crescents on biopsy → hallmark of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
  2. Pauci-immune pattern → minimal or absent immune complex deposition on IF microscopy.
    • This is most commonly associated with ANCA-associated vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Microscopic polyangiitis).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anti-GBM antibody: relevant in Goodpasture’s syndrome (crescentic GN with linear IgG deposition). Not pauci-immune.

 

Option C. Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibody:  marker for primary membranous nephropathy, not RPGN.

 

Option D. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA): useful in lupus nephritis (immune complex GN with “full house” pattern), not pauci-immune

choices.text: A high-protein diet increases the kidneys ability to concentrate urine
High vasopressin increases the urea deposition in the medullary interstitium
Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by primary active transport
Helpful in creation of counter current mechanism

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the role of urea in renal function?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by primary active transport

 

  • Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by primary active transport 
  • False because UT-A transporters mediate facilitated diffusion, not primary active transport.
  • Urea movement is passive, concentration-gradient driven, though facilitated by specific urea transporters.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. A high-protein diet increases the kidneys’ ability to concentrate urine:  More protein → more urea generated → higher medullary osmotic gradient → better concentrating ability.

 

Option B. High vasopressin increases the urea deposition in the medullary interstitium:  Vasopressin (ADH) upregulates urea transporters (UT-A1, UT-A3) in the inner medullary collecting duct, promoting urea reabsorption → raises medullary interstitial osmolarity.

 

Option D. Helpful in creation of counter-current mechanism: 

Urea recycling between collecting ducts and loop of Henle maintains the medullary osmotic gradient essential for water reabsorption.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Urea is transported by urea transport proteins (UT-A) by primary active transport

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney? 

 

  1. It is the most common sporadic renal tumor
  2. Associated with loss of long arm of chromosome 3
  3. Arises from distal convoluted tubule
  4. Cells show intracellular accumulation of PAS + Diastase sensitive substance
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4  

 

Clear cell carcinoma is the most common type of sporadic RCC. Tumor cells accumulate glycogen and lipids (PAS +, diastase sensitive).

 

Option 2: Wrong → associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3 (3p), not long arm.

 

Option 3: Wrong → arises from proximal convoluted tubule, not DCT.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with sore throat, for which oral amoxicillin was prescribed. In a few days, the child developed flank pain and rash. Peripheral blood demonstrated eosinophilia, and urinalysis showed WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allergic Interstitial Nephritis

 

Drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction; presents with fever, rash, eosinophilia and sterile pyuria/WBC casts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: PSGN → occurs 2–3 weeks after throat infection, not within days; RBC casts seen.

 

Option C. Berger disease: IgA nephropathy, presents with hematuria after URI.

 

Option D. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): would show bacterial growth, not eosinophilia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient arrives at the emergency department. Laboratory results are as follows: pH: 7.34, Sodium: 135 mmol/L, Potassium: 5 mmol/L, Bicarbonate: 12 mmol/L, Chloride: 92 mmol/L, RBS: 450 mg/dL, pCO2 30mmHg. Given these laboratory findings, which of the following statements best describes the patient's acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DKA

 

Hyperglycemia with metabolic acidosis (low HCO₃⁻, compensatory low pCO₂). 

 

K⁺ appears high due to acidosis but total body K⁺ is low.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. RTA: metabolic acidosis but no hyperglycemia.

 

Option C. High-altitude travel: respiratory alkalosis, not metabolic.

 

Option D. Myasthenia gravis: neuromuscular disorder, unrelated.

questions.text: A decrease in GFR is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased Bowman's oncotic pressure

 

Normally, filtration decreases when Bowman's oncotic pressure falls, reducing the driving gradient for filtration.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Increased RBF: Usually raises GFR, not decreases.

 

Option B. Increased glomerular hydrostatic pressure: Increases GFR.

 

Option D. Decreased glomerular oncotic pressure: Would increase GFR.

choices.text: Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.text: Identify the correct match out of the following diuretics and the respective site of action:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

 

Acetazolamide and other CA inhibitors act at the PCT by blocking bicarbonate reabsorption, causing alkaline urine and metabolic acidosis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics → Collecting duct: Incorrect. Act mainly at PCT & descending limb of Loop of Henle, not collecting duct.

 

Option C. Thiazides → Loop of Henle: Incorrect. Act on early distal convoluted tubule (Na⁺/Cl⁻ symporter), not Loop of Henle.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists → Distal Convoluted tubule: Incorrect. Act on collecting duct (ENaC and Na⁺/K⁺ exchange), not DCT.

questions.text: A 25 year old patient of bipolar disorder on lithium therapy presented with polydipsia and polyuria. Investigations revealed increased low urinary osmolality. Which of the following channels are involved here?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AQP-2

 

  • Lithium therapy commonly causes nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. 
  • Lithium enters principal cells via ENaC and inhibits AQP-2 channels in the collecting ducts, impairing water reabsorption and leading to polyuria and dilute urine.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. (AQP-1): Located in PCT & descending loop of Henle, not affected by lithium.

 

Option C. (AQP-3): Found on basolateral membrane of collecting duct cells, important for water exit but not the primary target of lithium.

 

Option D. (AQP-4): Also on basolateral side of collecting duct & brain, unaffected in lithium nephrotoxicity.

questions.text:
Dialysis will be effective for which of the following? 

 

  1. Seizures
  2. Metabolic acidosis
  3. Peripheral neuropathy
  4. Uremic pericarditis
  5. Hyperkalemia
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Dialysis corrects acute, reversible metabolic complications of kidney failure. It effectively removes toxins (uremic encephalopathy causing seizures), corrects metabolic acidosis, helps in uremic pericarditis, and rapidly corrects life-threatening hyperkalemia.

 

  • 1 (Seizures): Caused by uremic encephalopathy → improves with dialysis.
  • 2 (Metabolic acidosis): Dialysis corrects severe acidosis by removing acids and adding bicarbonate.
  • 4 (Uremic pericarditis): An absolute indication for urgent dialysis → effective.
  • 5 (Hyperkalemia): Dialysis rapidly reduces potassium levels → life-saving in refractory cases.
  • 3 (Peripheral neuropathy): Chronic, irreversible damage → not effectively corrected by dialysis.

questions.text: Identify the areas marked C in the following diagram:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory alkalosis

 

A. Acute metabolic alkalosis:

 

  • Sudden rise in plasma bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) usually due to vomiting or diuretic use.
  • Respiratory compensation is rapid hypoventilation, but incomplete if onset is acute.

 

B. Acute respiratory alkalosis:

 

  • Sudden drop in CO₂ due to hyperventilation (e.g., anxiety, pain, hypoxia).
  • Kidneys haven’t yet compensated, so HCO₃⁻ remains near normal.

 

C. Chronic respiratory alkalosis:

 

  • Persistent low CO₂ leads to renal compensation with decreased HCO₃⁻ over days.
  • Seen in chronic hyperventilation due to lung disease or high altitude.

 

D. Chronic metabolic alkalosis:

 

  • Long-standing elevated HCO₃⁻ due to conditions like loop diuretics or hyperaldosteronism.
  • Respiratory compensation is slower, with hypoventilation, but chronic cases may also have secondary renal adjustments.

choices.text: Urine protein levels range from 30 mg/d to 300 mg/d
It is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetic patients
It is the earliest marker of diabetic nephropathy
It is detected by routine dipstick method

questions.text: Which of the following medications is incorrect about microalbuminuria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is detected by routine dipstick method

 

  • Microalbuminuria = urinary albumin excretion 30–300 mg/day, which is too low to be detected on routine dipstick tests. Instead, it requires special immunoassays or albumin-to-creatinine ratio measurement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine protein levels range from 30 mg/d to 300 mg/d: Correct → Range is 30–300 mg/day.

 

Option B. It is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetic patients: Correct → Strong independent predictor of CV morbidity & mortality in diabetics.

 

Option C. It is the earliest marker of diabetic nephropathy: Correct → Recognized as the earliest clinical marker of diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of breathlessness on lying down and chest pain. He was diagnosed to have congestive cardiac failure and was administered torsemide. This drug inhibits which of the following type of transport mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secondary active Cotransport

 

  • Torsemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle.
  • It blocks the Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ symporter, which is a secondary active cotransporter (driven by Na⁺ gradient created by Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase).
  • This inhibition reduces reabsorption of Na⁺, Cl⁻, and K⁺ → causing diuresis, ↓preload, and relief of symptoms in CCF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary active transport: Carried out by Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase, not inhibited by torsemide.

 

Option C. Facilitated diffusion: Passive, carrier-mediated transport (e.g., GLUT transporters).

 

Option D: Secondary active Counter-transport: Seen in Na⁺/Ca²⁺ exchanger; not the target of torsemide.

.

choices.text: Increase blood flow to cortex and medulla
Increase blood flow to cortex and decrease blood flow to medulla
Decrease blood flow to cortex as well as medulla
Decrease blood flow to cortex and increase blood flow to medulla

questions.text: What is the effect of prostaglandins on renal blood flow?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase blood flow to cortex and decrease blood flow to medulla

 

PGs just vasodilate everywhere → but renal circulation is not uniform.

 

The cortex gets ~90% of renal blood flow. PGs amplify this bias → cortex increases further, medulla relatively decreases.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option C. Decrease blood flow to cortex as well as medulla: Decreased both is what happens with NSAIDs (PG inhibition).

 

Option D. Decrease blood flow to cortex and increase blood flow to medulla: Opposite of physiology.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who has been on dialysis for 2 years presents with bone pain and bowing of legs. Further evaluation reveals hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia. What is the initial treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevelamer 

 

Clinical Clues

 

  • 50-year-old on dialysis → chronic kidney disease
  • Presents with renal osteodystrophy: bone pain, bowing of legs
  • Labs: hyperphosphatemia + secondary hyperparathyroidism

 

Key Pathophysiology

 

  • In CKD → ↓ GFR → ↓ phosphate excretion → hyperphosphatemia
  • High phosphate binds calcium → hypocalcemia
  • Hypocalcemia + low calcitriol → secondary hyperparathyroidism (high PTH)
  • Leads to renal osteodystrophy

 

Treatment Hierarchy

 

  1. First step = Control hyperphosphatemia
    • Use phosphate binders like Sevelamer (non-calcium binder).
  2. After phosphate control → add activated vitamin D (Calcitriol) if hypocalcemia persists.
  3. Cinacalcet (calcimimetic) is used for refractory severe secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  4. Pamidronate (bisphosphonate) is for osteoporosis / malignancy hypercalcemia, not used here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitriol: Worsens hyperphosphatemia initially, so not the first choice.

 

Option C. Pamidronate: Not useful in secondary hyperparathyroidism of CKD.

 

Option D. Cinacalcet: Used if PTH remains uncontrolled after binders + vitamin D.

questions.text: Several hormones regulate the tubular reabsorption of water and electrolytes at different sites in the nephron physiologically in a patient. Which of the following combination is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aldosterone in cortical collecting duct

 

Hormonal control of nephron segments

 

Angiotensin II → Acts mainly on proximal tubule (↑ Na⁺ & water reabsorption via Na-H exchange).

 

Aldosterone → Acts on principal cells of cortical collecting duct (↑ Na⁺ reabsorption, ↑ K⁺ & H⁺ secretion).

 

ADH (vasopressin) → Acts on collecting duct (via V2 receptors → AQP2 insertion → ↑ water reabsorption).

 

ANP (Atrial natriuretic peptide) → Inhibits Na⁺ reabsorption in collecting ducts & distal tubule, dilates afferent arteriole, ↑ GFR.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Angiotensin in distal tubule: Wrong, acts at proximal tubule.

 

Option C. ADH in proximal tubule: Wrong, ADH acts at collecting duct, not proximal.

 

Option D. ANP in loop of Henle: Wrong, acts mainly at collecting duct & distal tubule.

questions.text: Which of the following ions in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) K⁺

 

  • K⁺  – Potassium recycling into the lumen creates lumen-positive potential, which is responsible for resorption of divalent ions (Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺).

 

Concept:

 

  • In the TAL, the Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ symporter (NKCC2) transports Na⁺, K⁺, and Cl⁻ into the cell.
  • K⁺ then leaks back into the lumen via ROMK channels, making the lumen positively charged.
  • This lumen-positive potential drives the paracellular reabsorption of divalent cations such as Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺.

 

Other Option: 

 

Option A. Na⁺: Essential for transport but not the main ion generating lumen positivity.

 

Option C. HCO₃⁻ : Not involved in TAL ion resorption.

 

Option D. H⁺: Mainly involved in proximal tubule (Na⁺-H⁺ exchange), not TAL cation reabsorption.

questions.text: A patient, urine flow rate is 10 mL/min; plasma inulin is 2 mg/mL; and urine inulin is 25 mg/mL. Which of the following is true assuming GFR to be normal?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inulin clearance = GFR

 

Inulin is the gold standard marker for GFR measurement because it is freely filtered at the glomerulus, not secreted, not reabsorbed, and not metabolized; hence its clearance equals GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inulin clearance > GFR: False, only occurs if substance is secreted (e.g., PAH).

 

Option C. Inulin clearance < GFR: False, only occurs if substance is reabsorbed (e.g., glucose, urea).

 

Option D. GFR cannot be calculated: Incorrect, here GFR is directly measurable from inulin clearance.

choices.text: Presence of carbonic anhydrase in luminal membrane
Lack of Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase in the basolateral membrane
Possession of brush border on luminal membrane

questions.text: What differentiates the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) from the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Presence of ‘tight’ tight junctions 

 

  • The distal convoluted tubule has tight tight junctions which make it less leaky than the proximal tubule, allowing precise regulation of ion and water reabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Presence of carbonic anhydrase in luminal membrane: Present in PCT, not unique to DCT.

 

Option B. Lack of Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase in the basolateral membrane: DCT has Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase for active sodium reabsorption.

 

Option C. Possession of brush border on luminal membrane: Brush border is characteristic of PCT, not DCT.
