pH 7.53, PaCo2 22, HCO3 22, Anion gap normal

questions.text: A 4-week-old, full-term boy is brought to the emergency department due to vomiting. His parents describe the emesis as undigested formula without blood or bile. The vomiting occurs after feeds and has increased in frequency and force over the past 3 days. Examination shows a sunken anterior fontanelle and dry mucous membranes. Arterial blood gas analysis is most likely to reveal which of the following sets of values?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) pH 7.48, PaCo2 46, HCO3 34, Anion gap normal

 

  • The infant presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting, classic for pyloric stenosis, leading to loss of gastric H⁺. 
  • This causes metabolic alkalosis with elevated HCO₃⁻ and normal anion gap.
  • Respiratory compensation occurs via hypoventilation, raising PaCO₂ slightly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. pH 7.29, PaCo2 30, HCO3 14, Anion gap elevated: Represents metabolic acidosis, not consistent with vomiting.

 

Option B. pH 7.30, PaCo2 50, HCO3 28, Anion gap normal: pH low (acidosis), inconsistent with vomiting-induced alkalosis.

 

Option D. pH 7.53, PaCo2 22, HCO3 22, Anion gap normal: Alkalemia present but HCO₃ normal; does not match gastric H⁺ loss physiology.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of lower extremity swelling and frothy urine. He has a history of chronic hepatitis C infection. Physical examination shows 3+ pitting edema of the lower legs and ankles. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased lipoproteins

 

  • The patient has nephrotic syndrome (proteinuria, edema, frothy urine) secondary to HCV-associated membranous nephropathy. 
  • Loss of proteins in urine triggers the liver to synthesize albumin and lipoproteins, leading to hyperlipidemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased cholesterol: Incorrect, cholesterol is typically elevated in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Increased antithrombin III: Incorrect, antithrombin III is lost in urine, increasing thrombotic risk.

 

Option D. Increased immunoglobulins: Incorrect, immunoglobulins are lost in urine, not increased.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the clinic with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

 

  • The patient has COPD with elevated pCO₂ (60 mmHg) and low pH (7.3), indicating respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation. 
  • HCO₃⁻ is only mildly elevated (28 mEq/L), showing that renal/metabolic compensation is still inadequate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Incorrect, patient is hypoventilating, not hyperventilating.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Incorrect, pH is low, not high.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Incorrect, HCO₃⁻ is not sufficiently high for full compensation.

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopy image showing deposits in the kidney. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous nephropathy

 

Key points from EM:

 

  • Electron-dense deposits are seen subepithelially (between the podocyte and GBM).

 

  • This is characteristic of primary or secondary membranous nephropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Goodpasture syndrome: Anti-GBM disease; EM shows linear IgG deposits, not subepithelial electron-dense deposits.

 

Option B. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN): EM shows subendothelial or mesangial deposits with GBM splitting (“tram-track” appearance).

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: EM shows podocyte foot process effacement but no deposits.

 

Classic clue: Subepithelial electron-dense deposits → Membranous nephropathy.

questions.text: 71-year-old man has had decreased urine output <500 mL per day for the past 3 days. Physical examination shows vital signs with temperature 37° C, pulse 88/min, respiratory rate 18/min, and blood pressure 85/60 mm Hg. He has peripheral edema and diffuse rales on auscultation of the chest. Urinalysis shows specific gravity 1.019 and no protein, blood, glucose, ketones, WBCs, RBCs, or casts. His serum creatinine is 3.3 mg/dL, and urea nitrogen is 62 mg/dL. The fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is <1%. Which of the following underlying conditions is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

  • The patient has features of prerenal azotemia (low BP, FENa <1%, high BUN/Cr ratio) due to reduced effective arterial blood volume.
  • The presence of edema and pulmonary congestion suggests heart failure, most likely due to dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Membranous nephropathy: Causes nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria, not seen here.

 

Option C. ATN: Would show FENa >2% and muddy brown casts, absent here.

 

Option D. Urothelial carcinoma: Presents with hematuria, not prerenal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following can be given to a patient with eGFR of <30?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metolazone

 

  • Metolazone is a thiazide-like diuretic effective even at low GFR (<30), often combined with loop diuretics in refractory edema.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Chlorothiazide: Ineffective at low GFR, works only when renal function is preserved.

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Ineffective when GFR <30.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Loses efficacy at low GFR.

choices.text: Serum sodium ↓, Tubular flow ↑, Filtrate osmolality ↑
Serum sodium ↓, Tubular flow ↓, Filtrate osmolality ↓
Serum sodium ↑, Tubular flow —, Filtrate osmolality ↑
Serum sodium —, Tubular flow ↓, Filtrate osmolality ↑

questions.text: A 62-year-old hypertensive man presents with headache and altered consciousness. CT shows right basal ganglia hemorrhage with midline shift. Mannitol is given IV. What is the expected acute effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum sodium ↓, Tubular flow ↑, Filtrate osmolality ↑

 

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that increases tubular flow and filtrate osmolality. 
  • Water shifts from intracellular to extracellular, diluting sodium (↓ serum sodium).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Wrong: Tubular flow increases, not decreases, with mannitol.

 

Option C. Wrong: Sodium decreases, not increases.

 

Option D. Wrong: Tubular flow increases, not decreases.

questions.text: What is a patient's urine analysis most likely to show if they have hematuria and hypercalciuria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isomorphic RBCs

 

  • Hypercalciuria predisposes to nephrolithiasis, which causes non-glomerular hematuria.
  • This presents as isomorphic RBCs on urinalysis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. RBC casts: Suggest glomerulonephritis, not stone disease.

 

Option C. Nephrotic proteinuria: Not related to hypercalciuria.

 

Option D. Eosinophiluria: Seen in drug-induced interstitial nephritis.

choices.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

 

  • Curve A: Shows rapid reduction to zero, consistent with glucose, which is almost completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.
  • Curve B: Shows partial loss, consistent with bicarbonate, which is reabsorbed but not completely.
  • Curve C: Remains constant at 100%, characteristic of inulin, which is filtered but neither reabsorbed nor secreted used to measure GFR.
  • Curve D: Rises above 100%, matching PAH (para-aminohippuric acid), which is both filtered and secreted such that almost all PAH entering the kidney is excreted—used to measure renal plasma flow

questions.text:
72-year-old woman is brought to the office by her daughter for evaluation of leg swelling  since 3 months.  The patient has had fatigue and joint pains for the past several years, which she attributes to old age. The daughter states that the patient seems tired all the time, barely eats anything, and "is just not herself." The patient takes no medication and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min and regular. The lungs are clear on auscultation and heart sounds are normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination of the lower extremities reveals 3+ pitting edema. There are scattered ecchymoses, and hand examination findings are shown.

 

 

 

Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL

 

Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL

 

Glucose: 94 mg/dL

 

Allbumin: 2.8 g/dL

 

Urinalysis reveals 4+ protein with no cells or casts. A renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)

 

 

Patient is suffering from Rheumatoid Arthritis which is associated with secondary amyloidosis in which kidney is most common affected organ. Image shows congo red stained histological image of amyloidosis [AA type].

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. This pink material: Is consistent with a hyaline thrombus within a capillary loop, seen in Thrombotic micro-angiopathy such as HUS or TTP.

 

Option B. Classical of Diabetic nephropathy: [kimmelstein Wilson lesion].

 

Option D. Suggestive of Malignant arteriosclerosis: Onion peel layer lesion.

choices.text: Persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a two-week history of fatigue, lower extremity edema, and frothy urine. He has no history of serious illnesses. Physical examination shows symmetric pitting edema of lower extremities. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria.  Electron microscopy of the specimen obtained from kidney biopsy shows dense deposits within glomerular basement membrane. Immunofluorescence microscopy is positive for C3, not immunoglobulins. Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism that explains this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway

 

  • This is dense deposit disease (type II membranoproliferative GN) where C3 is deposited due to uncontrolled alternative complement activation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anti-GBM-antibodies: Seen in Goodpasture’s disease, not here.

Option B. Circulating immune complexes: Seen in post-streptococcal GN and SLE.

Option D. Cell-mediated injury: Seen in minimal change disease, not with dense deposits.

choices.text: Inhibition of sodium reabsorption in medullary collecting duct

questions.text: Which of these is not an action of atrial natriuretic peptide?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mesangial constriction

 

  • ANP dilates afferent arterioles, reduces sodium reabsorption in PCT and collecting duct, and relaxes mesangial cells.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Afferent arteriole dilation: Correct action of ANP.

 

Option C. Decreased sodium absorption in PCT: True effect of ANP.

 

Option D. Inhibition of sodium reabsorption in medullary collecting duct: Also true effect.

choices.text: Get USG to rule out obstructive uropathy

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever and joint pains. He is being treated with cephalexin for a skin infection. His urine has turned darker. His temperature is 38.5° C (101.3° F), blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 15/min. Examination shows a skin rash; examination otherwise shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows: 8 RBCs/HPF, 12 WBCs/HPF with white cell casts, eosinophiluria, and a mild degree of proteinuria. Laboratory studies show a BUN of 40 mg/dl and serum creatinine of 2.2 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Discontinue cephalexin

 

This is acute interstitial nephritis due to cephalexin—drug should be stopped immediately.

 

Option B) Start IV fluids: Won’t resolve underlying problem.

 

Option C) Start oral ciprofloxacin: Not needed; no infection here.

 

Option D) Get USG: Not indicated unless obstruction suspected.

questions.text:
Which of the following sodium transporters are present maximally in early part of PCT?

 

  1. Na-K-ATPase
  2. Na-glucose cotransport
  3. Na-H antiporter
  4. Na-HCO3 symporter
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

  • In early PCT, sodium is reabsorbed with glucose (SGLT), via Na-H exchanger, and Na-K-ATPase drives the process.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 3, 4, 1: Includes HCO3 symporter, which is more distal.

 

Option B. 4, 2: Incomplete set.

 

Option D. 1, 4: Misses glucose and H+ exchange.

choices.text: Cuboidal epithelial cells of the proximal tubules
Endothelial cells of the efferent arteriole
Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole

questions.text: Scientists studying the kidney's response to hypoperfusion apply a clip to a pig's right renal artery that reduces blood flow to the kidney by about 7 %. After 6 months, they perform a right nephrectomy and examine the glomeruli and tubules microscopically. Which of the following cell types would be most likely to undergo hyperplasia as a result of the clip placement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole

 

  • These are juxtaglomerular cells that hyperplasia under chronic low perfusion due to increased renin secretion.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cuboidal epithelial cells of the proximal tubules: No hyperplasia here.

 

Option B. Endothelial cells of the efferent arteriole: Not involved.

 

Option C. Intraglomerular mesangial cells: Can proliferate in GN, not in hypoperfusion.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is produced by:

 

1. Kidney
2. Liver
3. Spleen
4. Lung
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

  • EPO is mainly from kidney (peritubular interstitial cells), with minor fetal contribution from liver.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 1 only: Not fully correct as liver also contributes.

 

Option B. 2 only: Incorrect, kidney is main site.

 

Option D. 2, 3, 4: Spleen/lung don’t produce EPO.

choices.text: Serum osmolarity increased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone increased
Serum osmolarity decreased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone decreased
Serum osmolarity increased, Urine sodium decreased, Serum aldosterone increased
Serum osmolarity decreased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone increased

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by staff of the group home where he resides because of worsening confusion for the past week. He has a history of major depressive disorder and had an ischemic stroke 4 months ago. Current medications are aspirin and sertraline. His pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist oral mucosa, normal skin turgor, and no peripheral edema. While in the waiting room, he has a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 119 mEq/L and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone concentration. Which of the following sets of additional laboratory is likely in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum osmolarity decreased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone decreased

 

  • This is SIADH—low serum osmolality, high urine sodium, and suppressed RAAS.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Serum osmolarity increased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone increased: Wrong, dilutional hyponatremia decreases it.

Option C. Serum osmolarity increased, Urine sodium decreased, Serum aldosterone increased: Not SIADH.

 

Option D. Serum osmolarity decreased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone increased: Not possible, as RAAS is suppressed.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of gradually worsening facial and lower extremity swelling. She has had a 4-kg weight gain during this time. Her blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema and 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. A 24-hour collection of urine shows 4.0 g of proteinuria. Microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen shows thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy shows dense subepithelial deposits. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-phospholipse A2 receptor antibodies

 

  • This is membranous nephropathy, associated with anti-PLA2R antibodies.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Anti-MPO: Seen in microscopic polyangiitis.

 

Option C. Anti-streptolysin O antibodies: Post-streptococcal GN.

 

Option D. Anti-proteinase 3 antibodies: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of high fever and confusion for the past 10 hours. His wife reports that 1 week ago he underwent an emergency appendectomy. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 132/min, and blood pressure is 74/46 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person. Physical examination shows a surgical wound in the right lower quadrant with purulent discharge. The skin is warm and dry. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 138 mEq/L, potassium concentration of 3.7 mEq/L, and lactate concentration of 3.5 mEq/L (N = 0.5-2.2 mEq/L). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Respiratory fatigue

 

  • Septic shock with fatigue → hypoventilation leads to respiratory acidosis on top of lactic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperventilation: Early sepsis, not late.

 

Option B. Primary adrenal insufficiency: Not suggested here.

 

Option C. Salicylate toxicity: Not related to presentation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to progressive confusion and lethargy over the past several hours. The patient has no significant medical history but he has been depressed since a recent breakup with his girlfriend. He works at an automotive repair shop, and one of his coworkers reported seeing the patient consume antifreeze prior to symptom onset. Blood pressure is 110/66 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 24/min. Bilateral costovertebral angles are tender to percussion. Bladder catheterization yields a small amount of bloody urine. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on this patient's arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) pH 7.3, pO2 95, pCO2 24, HCO3 19

 

  • Ethylene glycol poisoning → high anion gap metabolic acidosis with partial respiratory compensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH 7.1, pO2 47, pCO2 45, HCO3 19:Low pO2 → Not seen.

 

Option C. pH 7.6, pO2 95, pCO2 18, HCO3 40:Metabolic alkalosis → Not relevant.

 

Option D. pH 7.4, pO2 95, pCO2 24, HCO3 29: Normal ABG → Wrong.

questions.text:
54-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to several hours of severe epigastric abdominal pain radiating to her back. She has also had nausea and several episodes of vomiting. The patient has a history of occasional upper abdominal pain after eating but has never had such severe symptoms. She has no other medical issues and takes no medications. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), blood pressure is 110/66 mm Hg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 24/min. The patient appears to be in moderate distress. Mucous membranes are dry. The abdomen is distended with marked epigastric tenderness. Bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Hematocrit: 48%

 

Leukocytes: 18,800/mm³

 

Total bilirubin: 2.2 mg/dL

 

Alkaline phosphatase: 370 U/L

 

Lipase: 2,192 U/L

 

Which of the following sets of renal findings are most expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

Explanation: Hypovolemia in acute pancreatitis → RAAS activation → ↑ renin, ↑ efferent resistance, ↑ Na reabsorption.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Low efferent resistance: Wrong.

 

Option C. All low: Not in shock.

 

Option D. Low renin: Wrong.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to worsening leg swelling for the past 2 months. She has also felt excessively tired and has had achy pain in her hands. Serum creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis is positive for proteinuria and hematuria. Light microscopy of samples from a kidney biopsy shows diffuse, global endocapillary hypercellularity. Direct immunofluorescence demonstrates staining with diffuse, global, granular staining of glomerular capillary walls by IgG, IgM, IgA, C1q, and C3. Electron microscopy will demonstrate which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subendothelial deposits

 

  • This is diffuse proliferative GN (often lupus nephritis), classically with subendothelial deposits.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Mesangial deposits: IgA nephropathy.

 

Option C. Subepithelial deposits: Membranous nephropathy.

 

Option D. Intra-membranous: Dense deposit disease.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder is brought to the emergency department after taking an undetermined number of pills. She is lethargic but arousable. She refuses to answer questions. Blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg and heart rate is 120/min and regular. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Sodium: 139 mEg/L

 

Potassium: 3.3 mEq/L

 

Chloride : 98 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate: 13 mEq/L

 

Arterial blood gases on room air

 

pH: 7.46

 

PaCO2: 19 mmHg

 

PaO2: 96 mmHg

 

Oxygen saturation: 99%

 

Which of the following best describes this patient's acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Low bicarb = metabolic acidosis, low CO2 = concurrent respiratory alkalosis → mixed disorder.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Acidosis + alkalosis (metabolic both) → Not fitting.

 

Option B. Respiratory acidosis → PaCO2 is low, so incorrect.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis → Not consistent with HCO3 13.

choices.text: Low renin, low aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium
High renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium
Low renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium
Low renin, low aldosterone, low angiotensin II, high potassium

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the OPD due to increasing headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Medical history is significant for a transient ischemic attack that led to a right carotid endarterectomy 5 years ago. Blood pressure is 220/120 mm Hg and pulse is 70/min. Bilateral abdominal bruits are present. Blood testing in this patient would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium

 

Bilateral renal artery stenosis → secondary hyperaldosteronism with RAAS activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low renin, low aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium: Not stenosis.

 

Option C. Low renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium: Not possible here.

 

Option D. Low renin, low aldosterone, low angiotensin II, high potassium: Hyporeninemic states.

questions.text: A patient has hyperkalemia, raised uric acid levels and is going through hemodialysis. While this, patient develops drowsiness, had a seizure and got hypotensive. What can be given in treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol

 

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic, used to reduce cerebral edema in dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nesiritide: BNP analog for CHF, not here.

 

Option C. Ethacrynic acid: Loop diuretic, not first choice.

 

Option D. Bumetanide: Loop diuretic, not used here.

questions.text:
60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to bilateral flank pain and hematuria. Medical history is significant for recurrent urinary tract infections and hypothyroidism. Blood pressure is 130/80 mm g and pulse is 80/min. CT scan of the abdomen is shown below:

 

 

Urinalysis for this patient would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) pH 8.0

 

  • Recurrent UTIs, especially with urease-producing bacteria (like Proteus mirabilis), can alkalinize urine, leading to pH ≥8.
  • Alkaline urine promotes struvite stone formation, which explains the flank pain and hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4+ protein: Seen in nephrotic syndrome, not typical for UTI or stones.

 

Option B. Eosinophils: Seen in allergic interstitial nephritis, not in UTIs or stones.

 

Option D. RBC casts: Suggest glomerular origin hematuria (glomerulonephritis), not UTI-related stones.

 

Key point: Recurrent UTIs → alkaline urine (pH 8) → struvite stones.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is hospitalized for acute chest pain and undergoes PCI. His serum creatinine is unchanged 3 days post-procedure, but from day 4 slowly rises to a peak of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis demonstrates no proteinuria or red blood cells, and a few granular casts are present. Serum complement is low. Blood counts show eosinophilia.  Which one of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atheroembolic disease

 

Atheroembolic renal disease occurs after vascular procedures (like PCI), due to cholesterol crystal embolization. It presents with rising creatinine days after procedure, eosinophilia, low complement, and bland urine sediment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic interstitial nephritis: Typically shows fever, rash, eosinophiluria, and WBC casts, not low complement.

 

Option B. CIN: Contrast nephropathy occurs within 24–48 hours, not delayed rise after 3–5 days.

 

Option D. RPGN: Characterized by rapid renal failure, hematuria, RBC casts, not seen here.

choices.text: Alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen
Alpha 5 chain of type IV collagen

questions.text: 26-year-old previously healthy man comes to the OPD with a 3-week history of shortness of breath, cough, and hemoptysis preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg and pulse is 86/min and regular. Physical examination reveals bilateral inspiratory crackles and lower extremity edema. His creatinine is 4.1 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria with dysmorphic red blood cells. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates are seen on chest x-ray. He is also found to have an increased carbon monoxide diffusing capacity (DLCO) on pulmonary function testing. Antibodies directed against which of the following is most likely to be associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen

 

This is Goodpasture syndrome, presenting with pulmonary hemorrhage + rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Caused by autoantibodies against the α3 chain of type IV collagen in basement membranes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beta-hemolytic streptococci: Cause post-streptococcal GN, not associated with lung hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Alpha 5 chain of type IV collagen: Mutation causes Alport syndrome, not autoimmune GN.

 

Option D. Double-stranded DNA: Antibodies are seen in lupus nephritis, not with pulmonary hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to generalized edema, fatigue, and dyspnea on exertion for 2 months. The patient has a 25-year history of poorly controlled rheumatoid arthritis. Urinalysis shows 4+ protein. A renal biopsy is performed. Which of the following histologic abnormalities is most likely to be seen in this patient's glomeruli?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deposition of amorphous material

 

Chronic inflammatory conditions (like RA) predispose to secondary amyloidosis with deposition of amorphous, eosinophilic material (amyloid) in glomeruli → nephrotic syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crescent formation: Seen in RPGN, not nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Diffuse hypercellularity: Typical of post-streptococcal GN.

 

Option D. IgA deposition: Suggests Berger’s disease (IgA nephropathy).

questions.text:
21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to diffuse muscle aches and weakness. He has also noticed darkening of his urine. The patient recently joined the military and was participating in rigorous training exercises in hot weather earlier in the day. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Sodium: 136 mEq/L

 

Potassium: 5.6 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate: 18 mEq/L

 

Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL

 

CK: 22,000 U/L (normal: 30-170)

 

Which of the following urine microscopy is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granular casts

 

This is rhabdomyolysis-induced acute tubular necrosis (ATN) → dark urine (myoglobinuria), hyperkalemia, high CK. ATN commonly shows granular (“muddy brown”) casts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysmorphic RBCs: Seen in glomerulonephritis.

 

Option B. Eosinophils: Seen in allergic interstitial nephritis.

 

Option D. Waxy casts: Seen in chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to vomiting blood. After appropriate resuscitation measures, he undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, which reveals a bleeding duodenal ulcer. During hospital day 2, the patient develops decreased urine output. Serum creatinine rises to 3.0 mg/dL from a baseline of 1.2 mg/dL. Renal biopsy shows patchy epithelial necrosis of the tubules, intratubular casts. Supportive care is provided. Several days later, his urine output significantly increases, and serum creatinine levels decline. Over the next few days, this patient is at highest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypokalemia

 

During recovery phase of ATN, patients develop polyuria due to impaired tubular reabsorption. This causes massive potassium loss → hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Seen in initial oliguric phase, not recovery phase.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis: More likely in maintenance phase.

 

Option D. Volume overload: Occurs in oliguric phase, not diuretic recovery phase.

choices.text: Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyvit D, normal 1,25 hydroxyVitD
Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyvit D, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD
High serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, low PTH, normal 25-hydroxyvit D, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD
Low serum calcium, low serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyvit D, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD

questions.text: 56-year-old man with chronic renal insufficiency due to polycystic kidney disease is evaluated for placement of an arteriovenous fistula for dialysis access. Blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. Examination shows 2+ bilateral edema of the lower extremities. Estimated glomerular filtration rate is 15 mL/min/1.73 m². Which of the following sets of laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyVitD, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD

 

This is secondary hyperparathyroidism due to CKD. Diseased kidneys cannot excrete phosphorus (→ ↑ phosphorus), and cannot activate vitamin D (→ ↓ 1,25 VitD), causing hypocalcemia and compensatory ↑ PTH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyVitD, normal 1,25 hydroxyVitD: Wrong, it’s low in CKD.

 

Option C. Low serum calcium, high serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyVitD, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD: Suggests hypercalcemia of malignancy, not CKD.

 

Option D. Low serum calcium, low serum phosphorus, high PTH, normal 25-hydroxyVitD, low 1,25 hydroxyVitD: Not seen in CKD; phosphorus retention causes hyperphosphatemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) was started on tolvaptan therapy. A few weeks later, he presents with symptoms of dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely mechanism behind these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased free water clearance

 

  • Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist.
  • By blocking V2 receptors in the collecting duct, water reabsorption is reduced, leading to aquaresis (excretion of free water without electrolyte loss).
  • This results in polyuria, thirst, and dry mouth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. V2 receptor agonism: Opposite effect; would decrease urine output.

 

Option C. Increased renal cAMP levels: Tolvaptan actually reduces cAMP-mediated cyst growth, not responsible for thirst.

 

Option D. Increase in urine osmolality: Tolvaptan decreases urine osmolality due to water loss.

 

Key point: Tolvaptan causes aquaresis → increased free water clearance → thirst and dry mouth.

questions.text: A 19-month-old girl is brought to the OPD due to a 2-month history of diarrhea. Her parents report that she has 3- 5 loose, non-bloody bowel movements daily with occasional episodes of vomiting. She was breastfed exclusively until age 9 months and has since had a well-varied diet including whole milk, fruits, vegetables, bread, and meats. However, the girl has been less interested in food over the past several weeks After laboratory evaluation, duodenal biopsy findings are shown in the exhibit. Which of the following would most likely improve this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified grain diet

 

  • The duodenal biopsy with villous atrophy in a toddler with chronic diarrhea suggests celiac disease (gluten-sensitive enteropathy).
  • The most effective therapy is removal of gluten-containing grains (wheat, rye, barley) → symptom improvement and mucosal healing.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Antibiotic therapy: Not indicated; no evidence of infection.

 

Option B. Enzyme supplementation: Pancreatic insufficiency unlikely here.

 

Option C. Modified dairy diet: Lactose intolerance may occur secondary but is not the primary cause.

 

Key point: Gluten-free diet is first-line therapy in pediatric celiac disease.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after an episode of large-volume hematemesis. Physical examination reveals a palpable spleen. Endoscopy shows bleeding esophageal varices. A liver biopsy performed 2 days later shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Portal vein thrombosis

 

  • The patient has portal hypertension (esophageal varices, splenomegaly) but a normal liver biopsy, indicating prehepatic cause.
  • Portal vein thrombosis obstructs portal flow → varices and splenomegaly, while the liver remains histologically normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long-term alcohol consumption: Would cause cirrhosis → abnormal biopsy.

 

Option B. Budd-Chiari syndrome: Hepatic vein obstruction → liver congestion, biopsy abnormal.

 

Option C. Constrictive pericarditis: Can cause hepatic congestion, but variceal bleeding less common.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is hospitalized due to worsening confusion and vomiting of blood for the past 2 days. Medical history is notable for irritability and declining school performance over the past year. He is oriented to person but disoriented to time and place. During hospitalization, the patient rapidly deteriorates and passes away. Autopsy examination reveals Nodular liver, Splenomegaly, Basal ganglia atrophy with increased copper content. The most likely cause of this patient’s condition is an abnormality in which of the following physiologic processes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Biliary copper excretion

 

  • This is Wilson disease, a genetic disorder of ATP7B gene → defective copper excretion into bile → copper accumulation in liver, brain, and basal ganglia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum copper transporter defect: Refers to ceruloplasmin; not the primary problem.

 

Option C. Increased intestinal absorption: Normal in Wilson disease.

 

Option D. Decreased urinary excretion: Actually, urinary copper is elevated in Wilson disease.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a one-week history of diffuse abdominal pain. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows numerous scars and excoriations along both arms, scleral icterus, and tender hepatomegaly. Serum studies shown below:

 

 

Which of the following is least likely to be seen in the liver biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ground glass hepatocytes

 

  • Acute Hepatitis B infection: Biopsy shows ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes, spotty/focal necrosis, Councilman bodies (apoptotic hepatocytes), and confluent necrosis in severe cases.
  • Ground glass hepatocytes are a feature of chronic Hepatitis B infection due to HBsAg accumulation in hepatocyte endoplasmic reticulum.
  • Since the patient is in acute hepatitis (anti-HBc negative → very early), ground glass cells will not be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ballooning degeneration: Common in acute hepatitis, due to hepatocyte swelling and cytoskeletal damage.

 

Option C. Focal or spotty necrosis: Hallmark of acute viral hepatitis → scattered hepatocyte necrosis with lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Option D. Confluent necrosis of hepatocytes: Severe form in acute viral hepatitis, may progress to bridging necrosis and liver failure.

questions.text:
Noninvasive test to detect risk of hepatic fibrosis include? 

 

  1. Aspartate aminotransferases /platelet ratio
  2. Fibro scan
  3. Forns index 
  4. Serum laminin & serum hyaluronidase
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4 

 

  • AST/Platelet ratio index (APRI): A simple biochemical score used to predict significant fibrosis and cirrhosis.
  • FibroScan (Transient elastography): Ultrasound-based technique to measure liver stiffness → reliable noninvasive marker.
  • Forns index: A composite index (age, cholesterol, GGT, platelet count) → predicts fibrosis risk.
  • Serum laminin & serum hyaluronidase: Direct serum biomarkers that reflect extracellular matrix turnover and fibrosis.

 

Hence, all four listed methods are valid noninvasive tests.

questions.text: Patient affected with acute hepatitis B infection has currently come for follow up. Identify the serological marker marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-HBc Ab

 

  • In acute HBV infection, Anti-HBc IgM is the most reliable marker of recent infection.
  • It appears shortly after HBsAg and persists during the "window period" (when HBsAg has disappeared but Anti-HBs is not yet detectable).
  • Thus, in follow-up of acute HBV, the marker shown in the graph corresponds to Anti-HBc Ab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-HBe Ab: Indicates low infectivity; develops after seroconversion from HBeAg.

 

Option C. Anti-HBs Ab: Marker of recovery or immunity (post-infection or vaccination).

 

Option D. HBsAg: First marker to appear; indicates active infection but disappears before Anti-HBs develops.

choices.text: Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.
Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption.
Transferrin transcription increases in iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane

 

Iron is absorbed in the duodenum and proximal jejunum in its ferrous (Fe²⁺) form via DMT-1 transporters on the apical membrane. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) enhances absorption by reducing ferric (Fe³⁺) to ferrous (Fe²⁺). After absorption, iron is oxidized back to ferric (Fe³⁺) to bind with transferrin in plasma. Hence, the statement that iron is converted from ferrous to ferric before absorption is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoferritin is the storage form: Correct. Apoferritin binds Fe²⁺ to form ferritin, the intracellular storage form of iron.

 

Option C. Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption: Correct. It maintains iron in the ferrous state, enhancing absorption.

 

Option D. Transferrin transcription increases in iron deficiency anemia: Correct. This upregulation improves transport of absorbed iron.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct regarding the polyposis condition shown below?

 

 

  1. High risk of pancreatic carcinoma
  2. Loss of heterozygosity in the STK11 gene
  3. Multiple Gl polyps
  4. Autosomal recessive
  5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3 

 

The features describe Peutz–Jeghers syndrome (hamartomatous GI polyps, mucocutaneous pigmentation) caused by mutations in STK11 (LKB1) with loss of heterozygosity; it is associated with multiple GI polyps and an increased lifetime risk of several malignancies including pancreatic carcinoma.

 

  • High risk of pancreatic carcinoma – Peutz–Jeghers syndrome patients have markedly increased risk of GI (including pancreatic), breast, ovarian, and cervical cancers.
  • Loss of heterozygosity in the STK11 gene – The syndrome is caused by germline mutations in STK11/LKB1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 19.
  • Multiple GI polyps – Characterized by hamartomatous polyps throughout the GI tract, especially small intestine, often causing intussusception and bleeding.
  • Autosomal recessive – Incorrect; Peutz–Jeghers follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern with variable penetrance.
  • Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) – Seen in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), not Peutz–Jeghers, hence not associated.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of intermittent watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. He has had a 12-kg weight loss during this period. He has also had episodic pain of the ankle, wrist, and knee joints during the past 5 years. An endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is performed. Histopathologic examination of a tissue specimen shows foamy macrophages in the lamina propria with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive inclusions. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intracellular gram positive bacteria

 

This is Whipple’s disease due to Tropheryma whipplei. It causes diarrhea, weight loss, arthralgias, and PAS-positive foamy macrophages in lamina propria. The organism is an intracellular gram-positive bacillus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multinucleated trophozoites: Seen in Giardia lamblia, causes foul-smelling steatorrhea, not PAS+ inclusions.

 

Option B. Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies: Characteristic of celiac disease, associated with villous atrophy.

 

Option D. Anti-saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies: Seen in Crohn’s disease, not Whipple’s disease.

 

Whipple's disease

questions.text:
50-year-old gentleman presented with progressive abdominal distension with shifting dullness on examination. Ascitic fluid analysis given below. What is the likely diagnosis? 

S. Albumin - 3g/dl

S. Protein - 7g/dl

Ascitic Albumin - 1g/dl

Ascitic protein - 1.5g/dl

Cells - 125, 90% Lymphocytes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cirrhosis

 

SAAG = 3 – 1 = 2.0 (>1.1) → portal hypertension.

Ascitic protein = 1.5 g/dL (low), consistent with cirrhosis-related ascites. TB and CHF usually show high protein ascites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congestive heart failure: High SAAG with high protein (>2.5 g/dL), unlike this case.

 

Option B. Budd-Chiari syndrome: High SAAG with high protein ascites due to hepatic vein obstruction.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Low SAAG (<1.1), lymphocytic but with high protein ascites.

choices.text: Gastric H⁺ increases, Duodenal HCO₃⁻ increased, Duodenal Cl⁻ no change
Gastric H⁺ decreases, Duodenal HCO₃⁻ decreased, Duodenal Cl⁻ no change
Gastric H⁺ decreases, Duodenal HCO₃⁻ increased, Duodenal Cl⁻ decreases
Gastric H⁺ decreases, Duodenal HCO₃⁻ increased, Duodenal Cl⁻ increases

questions.text: During a study on gastrointestinal hormones, a volunteer is administered the hormone secreted by S cells. Which of the following changes most likely represent the effect of this hormone on gastric and duodenal secretions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastric H⁺ decreases, Duodenal HCO₃⁻ increased, Duodenal Cl⁻ decreases

 

S cells secrete secretin, which inhibits gastric acid secretion and stimulates pancreatic & biliary bicarbonate secretion. HCO₃⁻ secretion increases in exchange for Cl⁻, reducing luminal Cl⁻.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric H⁺ increases, Duodenal HCO₃⁻ increased, Duodenal Cl⁻ no change: Secretin decreases gastric acid, so this is incorrect.

 

Option B. Gastric H⁺ decreases, Duodenal HCO₃⁻ decreased, Duodenal Cl⁻ no change: Secretin increases HCO₃⁻, not decreases.

 

Option D. Gastric H⁺ decreases, Duodenal HCO₃⁻ increased, Duodenal Cl⁻ increases: Secretin drives HCO₃⁻/Cl⁻ exchange, so Cl⁻ decreases instead.

choices.text: Incomplete penetrance of homozygotic HFE mutations

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman dies of congestive heart failure. Autopsy shows a dilated heart with brownish pigmentation of the myocardium. Light microscopy of her liver after Prussian blue staining is shown in the image below. The patient's brother died of profuse upper gastrointestinal bleeding at age 43. Assuming this patient's disorder is hereditary, which of the following most likely contributed to the delayed onset of her disease compared to her brother?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Premenopausal menstrual bleeding

 

  • This patient had Hereditary Hemochromatosis (HFE gene mutation) causing iron overload (brown myocardium, Prussian blue–positive iron in liver).
  • In men, iron accumulation begins earlier because they do not have a mechanism of iron loss.
  • In women, menstrual blood loss before menopause delays the onset of clinical disease (cardiomyopathy, cirrhosis, diabetes).
  • Hence, the brother developed complications earlier, while this woman manifested later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heterozygosity for HFE gene mutation: Would not cause severe disease; homozygosity is usually required.

 

Option B. High-dose vitamin C intake: Accelerates iron absorption, but would worsen rather than delay disease.

 

Option C. Incomplete penetrance of homozygotic HFE mutations: Explains variability in expression but not consistent sex-related delay.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) has a direct spasmolytic action on gastrointestinal (GI) smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mebeverine

 

Mebeverine is a musculotropic antispasmodic drug that directly relaxes GI smooth muscle by blocking calcium influx and inhibiting potassium efflux. It acts locally without anticholinergic side effects, making it particularly useful in IBS patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dicyclomine: An anticholinergic that relieves GI spasm via muscarinic blockade, but does not act directly on smooth muscle.

 

Option B. Scopolamine: A strong antimuscarinic used in motion sickness, not preferred in IBS due to systemic side effects.

 

Option D. Racecadotril: An enkephalinase inhibitor used in secretory diarrhea; no spasmolytic effect on GI smooth muscle.

choices.text: It is associated with ulcerative colitis
There is no effective medical therapy

questions.text:
A 35-year-old patient is being evaluated for jaundice. ERCP and lab values are shown below.

 

Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST) - 55 U/L

Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT) - 56 U/L

Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) - 213 U/L

Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) - 75 U/L

Total Bilirubin - 1.2 mg/dL

 

 

Which of the following statement is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Biopsy shows florid duct lesion

 

The patient’s findings suggest Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) – cholestatic enzyme pattern (↑ALP, ↑GGT) with near-normal transaminases. PSC is strongly associated with ulcerative colitis and is a premalignant condition (risk of cholangiocarcinoma). There is currently no effective medical therapy; liver transplantation is definitive. The term florid duct lesion is actually seen in Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC), not PSC — hence option C is false.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is associated with ulcerative colitis: Correct, up to 70% of PSC patients have UC.

 

Option B. It is a premalignant condition: Correct, PSC predisposes to cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option D. There is no effective medical therapy: Correct, only liver transplant is curative.

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? 

 

  • HBsAg - NR
  • Anti HBs - NR 
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR 
  • Anti HBc total - positive
  • HBeAg - NR
  • Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

The only marker that is positive here is anti-HBc total, which indicates prior exposure to HBV. The absence of HBsAg and presence of anti-HBc total (but not IgM) suggests resolved past infection with recovery, not active or chronic disease. Vaccine-induced immunity shows only anti-HBs positivity, not anti-HBc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: Would show anti-HBc IgM positivity, which is absent here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Would show anti-HBs positivity only, not anti-HBc.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Would have persistent HBsAg positivity.

questions.text: 45-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of chronic diarrhea. He has lost almost 7 kg over the past year. He has no blood in the stool. A 24-hour stool collection shows fecal fat content of 10 g/day (normal <6 g/day). Stool microscopy shows no pathogens and no leukocytes. Serum electrolytes and renal function are within normal limits. The patient is given 25 g oral D-xylose solution, and his urinary excretion of D-xylose at 5 hours is 1.2 g (normal 4.5-7.5 g). After 4 weeks of treatment with rifaximin, the D-xylose test is repeated, and the urinary excretion at 5 hours is 1.3 g. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The D-xylose test evaluates intestinal mucosal absorption. The persistently low urinary excretion of D-xylose before and after antibiotics indicates a mucosal absorption defect, typical of celiac disease. In pancreatic insufficiency, D-xylose absorption remains normal because it does not require pancreatic enzymes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BOGS: Not a recognized clinical entity in this context.

 

Option C. Lactose intolerance: Causes osmotic diarrhea but does not affect D-xylose absorption.

 

Option D. Pancreatic insufficiency: Causes steatorrhea but D-xylose test remains normal.

questions.text: Which of the following are cells lining the isthmus of the gastric pits?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem cells  

 

The isthmus of gastric pits is primarily lined by stem cells, which act as progenitors and give rise to surface mucous cells, parietal cells, and chief cells. This ensures renewal of the gastric epithelium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chief cells: Located deeper in the glands (base), not in the isthmus.

 

Option C. Parietal cells: Found mostly in the neck of gastric glands, not at the isthmus lining.

 

Option D. Mucous cells: Line the surface and neck but not the isthmus itself.

questions.text:
Identify the true statements about IBD:

 

  1. Smoking and appendicectomy decrease the risk of UC 
  2. NOD2 and PTPN22 genes are implicated in the pathophysiology of CD
  3. Uveitis, peripheral arthritis, EN are more common with UC while PSC is more common with CD
  4. Rectal involvement with continuous disease and crypt abscess is associated with UC
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

UC (Ulcerative colitis): Risk decreases with smoking and appendicectomy. Rectal involvement with continuous disease and crypt abscesses is characteristic.

 

CD (Crohn’s disease): NOD2 and PTPN22 gene mutations are implicated.

 

Extraintestinal features: PSC is more common in UC (not CD), hence statement 3 is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 3, 4: Incorrect as statement 3 is wrong.

 

Option B. 2, 3, 4: Excludes the protective role of smoking/appendicectomy, so wrong.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Misses statement 1, which is true.

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient presents to the OPD with intermittent rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and mucous discharge. Histological examination showed the following lesion. What is the first-line management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sulfasalazine 

 

  • The patient’s symptoms (rectal bleeding, tenesmus, mucous discharge) and histology are consistent with Ulcerative Colitis (UC).
  • First-line management of mild to moderate UC is 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) compounds, such as Sulfasalazine or Mesalamine, which act topically in the colon to reduce inflammation.
  • Surgery (colectomy) is reserved for refractory disease, severe complications (toxic megacolon, perforation, dysplasia), or failure of medical therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical resection: Indicated in fulminant colitis, perforation, uncontrolled bleeding, or carcinoma risk, not first-line.

 

Option C. NSAIDs: Can worsen UC flares by increasing mucosal injury, hence contraindicated.

 

Option D. Antibiotics: Not routinely used; reserved for complications like superimposed infection.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband for lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days. She returned from a trip to Thailand 2 weeks ago. Her immunizations are up-to-date and she has never received blood products. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F). She is not oriented to person, place, or time. Examination shows jaundice and mild asterixis. Her prothrombin time is 18 sec (INR=2.0), serum alanine aminotransferase is 3911 U/L, and serum aspartate aminotransferase is 3724 U/L. This patient's current condition is most likely associated with increased titers of which of the following serum studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-HEV IgM

 

Clinical vignette summary

 

  • 33-year-old pregnant woman (24 weeks, G2P1)
  • Recent travel to Thailand (endemic area for Hepatitis E)
  • Acute illness: fever, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, altered sensorium, asterixis
  • Labs: markedly raised AST/ALT (>3000 U/L), prolonged PT/INR → acute fulminant hepatitis

 

Confirms acute HEV infection.

 

Key clue

 

Pregnancy + Fulminant hepatitis + Endemic country (Asia) → strongly suggests Hepatitis E virus (HEV).

 

  • HEV is transmitted fecal–orally (contaminated water, food).
  • In pregnancy (especially 2nd/3rd trimester), it carries very high risk of acute liver failure & maternal mortality (up to 25%).
  • Diagnosis: Anti-HEV IgM positivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HBe IgM: marker of acute HBV replication, not seen here.

 

Option B. HBsAg: indicates HBV infection (chronic/acute), not consistent with pregnancy-related fulminant hepatitis.

 

Option D. Anti-HCV IgG: indicates past HCV exposure, not acute fulminant hepatitis.

choices.text: Presence of bilirubin in the urine

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about obstructive jaundice?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased urobilinogen

 

In obstructive jaundice, bile cannot reach the intestine → urobilinogen production decreases → low/absent urobilinogen in urine.

 

Urobilinogen is not increased; instead, it decreases – incorrect statement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased direct bilirubin: Direct bilirubin rises due to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia – correct.

 

Option B. Increased alkaline phosphatase: ALP is elevated due to cholestasis – correct.

 

Option C. Presence of bilirubin in the urine: Conjugated bilirubin is water-soluble → appears in urine – correct.

choices.text: Anti-IgA tissue transglutaminase (TTG) is a key diagnostic marker
Modified Marsh criteria is used for histological classification
Anti-IgG gliadin antibodies are highly specific for celiac disease
HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are genetic markers associated with the disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements about celiac disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are genetic markers associated with the disease

 

Celiac disease is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8, not DQ6/DQ11.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-IgA TTG is a key diagnostic marker: Iga is the most sensitive and specific serological test – correct.

 

Option B. Modified Marsh criteria is used histologically: Marsh criteria classifies villous atrophy/crypt hyperplasia – correct.

 

Option C. Anti-IgG gliadin antibodies are less specific: mainly used in IgA deficiency – correct (but not “highly specific”).

questions.text: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MLH-1

 

  • This patient has Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC / Lynch syndrome).
  • It is caused by germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, most commonly MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2.
  • It leads to microsatellite instability → right-sided (proximal) colon cancer, often with endometrial, ovarian, gastric, urinary tract cancers.

  • Early onset and family clustering point to Lynch syndrome.

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tp53: Mutation seen in Li-Fraumeni syndrome and late stage of adenoma–carcinoma sequence, not in Lynch.

 

Option C. KRAS: Involved in adenoma → carcinoma progression in sporadic colorectal cancer.

 

Option D. APC: Gene mutated in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), associated with hundreds of polyps, not isolated right-sided cancer.

questions.text: 66-year-old woman comes to the office due to bloating, flatulence, and abdominal discomfort for the past 6 months. The patient has mild, intermittent, crampy abdominal pain that is unrelated to eating and does not improve after defecation. She also has 2 or 3 loose, watery bowel movements daily. The patient has had no hematochezia, melena, vomiting, or unexpected weight loss. Medical history is significant for degenerative disk disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. Medications include insulin, amlodipine, and oxycodone. Faecal occult blood test is negative. Complete blood count is normal. Serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c is 9.3%. Carbohydrate breath testing using glucose is abnormal. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifaximin

 

  • The patient’s symptoms and positive glucose hydrogen breath test indicate Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO).
  • Risk factors: diabetes mellitus (autonomic neuropathy → impaired motility), opioid use, CKD.
  • First-line therapy = non-absorbable antibiotics like rifaximin, which reduce bacterial overgrowth while limiting systemic side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluten-free diet: Used for celiac disease; negative occult blood and absence of malabsorption features make it unlikely.

 

Option B. PPI: May worsen SIBO by reducing gastric acid defense; not a treatment.

 

Option C. Pancreatic enzyme replacement: Used for exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (steatorrhea, weight loss, fat-soluble vitamin deficiency).

 

Key Point:

 

SIBO = bloating + diarrhea + positive breath test → treated with rifaximin (first-line).

questions.text: 62-year-old man comes for the evaluation of jaundice. Medical history is significant for uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and morbid obesity. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. BMl is 47 kg/m2.  Laboratory studies reveal elevated transaminases. A  liver biopsy is obtained, and trichrome staining shows the following. Which of the following cells is directly responsible for the histologic finding indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stellate (Ito) cells

 

  • Hepatic stellate (Ito) cells, located in the space of Disse, normally store vitamin A.
  • In chronic liver injury (eg, NAFLD/NASH, alcohol, hepatitis), stellate cells are activated by cytokines from Kupffer cells → transform into myofibroblast-like cells → secrete collagen → fibrosis/cirrhosis.
  • The trichrome stain highlights collagen deposition = hallmark of fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocytes: Epithelial cells of bile ducts; involved in cholestatic diseases, not fibrosis.

 

Option B. Hepatocytes: Undergo ballooning degeneration & necrosis but do not produce collagen directly.

 

Option C. Kupffer cells: Liver macrophages; release cytokines (eg, TGF-β) that activate stellate cells but are not the direct source of fibrosis.

choices.text: Had an accidental needlestick exposure at work
Had steamed oysters at a neighborhood restaurant
Had unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner

questions.text:
34-year-old woman comes to the OPD with recent onset of malaise. The patient works as a nurse at a local hospital and lives at home with her husband and 2-year-old son.  Physical examination is notable for hepatomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows:

Anti-HAV IgM Positive

Anti-HAV IgG negative

HBsAg negative

HBeAg negative

Anti-HBs positive

Anti-HBc negative

Anti-HBe negative

Anti-HCV negative

Which of the following is most likely to be elicited on further history taking?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Had steamed oysters at a neighborhood restaurant


Acute HAV infection is indicated by anti-HAV IgM positive (with IgG negative). Hepatitis A spreads fecal–orally, classically from contaminated shellfish (e.g., oysters) or food/water outbreaks. Her HBV panel (isolated anti-HBs positive with negative anti-HBc) is consistent with immunity due to vaccination, and HCV is negative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Had an accidental needlestick exposure at work: Parenteral risk for HBV/HCV, not HAV; her serology shows no acute HBV/HCV.

 

Option B. Had a blood transfusion: Transfusion-transmitted viral hepatitis is typically HCV/HBV; HAV is not blood-borne.

 

Option D. Had unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner: Sexual transmission is key for HBV; HAV is primarily fecal–oral and her HBV panel shows vaccine immunity.

choices.text: Decreased cholecystokinin release due to lack of enteral stimulation
Decreased cholesterol conversion to bile acids due to liver dysfunction
High cholesterol content of the nutritional fluids
Inadequate supplementation of essential fatty acids

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to acute-onset right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The patient had an extensive small bowel resection due to bowel ischemia a year ago and has been receiving total parenteral nutrition since then. Abdominal ultrasonography is shown below. Which of the following is most likely factor responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased cholecystokinin release due to lack of enteral stimulation 


Prolonged total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and lack of enteral feeding cause decreased CCK release, leading to gallbladder stasis and bile sludge/stone formation (acalculous cholecystitis or cholesterol sludge). Stasis is the primary mechanism linking TPN to gallbladder pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased cholesterol conversion to bile acids due to liver dysfunction: Decreased hepatic conversion of cholesterol to bile acids can worsen cholesterol supersaturation but is not the main mechanism in TPN-related stasis.

 

Option C. High cholesterol content of the nutritional fluids: High cholesterol content in TPN fluids is not a recognized cause—parenteral lipid emulsions do not directly produce gallstones via this route.

 

Option D. Inadequate supplementation of essential fatty acids: Essential fatty-acid deficiency causes systemic problems but is not the principal factor for TPN-associated gallbladder stasis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The patient is admitted to the hospital and treated with intravenous fluids and pain medication, but his condition fails to improve. An abdominal CT scan is shown below. The inappropriate activation of which of the following most likely initiated this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trypsinogen


Acute pancreatitis is initiated by the premature activation of trypsinogen to trypsin inside pancreatic acinar cells. Trypsin then activates other pancreatic proenzymes (eg, proelastase, prophospholipase, lipase), leading to autodigestion, necrosis, and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipase: Causes fat necrosis in pancreatitis, but it is activated downstream after trypsin.

 

Option B. Proelastase: When activated, degrades elastic fibers in vessel walls → hemorrhage, but this occurs after trypsin activation.

 

Option C. Prophospholipase: Contributes to membrane destruction and cell necrosis, but again is dependent on trypsin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician due to periodic reddening of her skin that is starting to become bothersome. The patient has also had persistent watery diarrhea and associated abdominal cramping for the last several months. Physical examination shows several, purple vascular lesions surrounding her nose. Urinary excretion of 5- hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) over 24 hours is increased. Abdominal imaging shows a tumor in the small intestine. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metastatic carcinoid


Carcinoid syndrome (flushing, watery diarrhea, bronchospasm, right-sided valvular lesions) occurs when serotonin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors metastasize to the liver (or originate outside the portal system), allowing vasoactive substances to bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism; elevated urinary 5-HIAA confirms excessive serotonin production. A small-intestinal carcinoid that has metastasized to the liver is the classic cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Localized adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinomas of the small bowel generally do not secrete serotonin and do not cause carcinoid syndrome.

 

Option B. Localized carcinoid: If confined to the gut without hepatic metastases, secreted serotonin is metabolized by the liver and usually does not produce systemic carcinoid syndrome.

 

Option D. Metastatic lymphoma: Lymphomas may involve the bowel but do not cause serotonin-mediated flushing/diarrhea or elevated 5-HIAA.

choices.text: Accumulation of hemoglobin in the intestine

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of increasing confusion and lethargy for the past 12 hours. He is oriented only to person. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 108/67 mm Hg. Examination shows abdominal distention and several erythematous, lacy lesions on the chest that blanch with pressure. His hands make a flapping motion when they are dorsiflexed. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Accumulation of hemoglobin in the intestine


This clinical picture (spider angiomas, ascites, asterixis, altered mental status) is hepatic encephalopathy from advanced liver disease. Gastrointestinal bleeding (accumulation of blood/hemoglobin in the gut) is a classic precipitant because hemoglobin is broken down by gut bacteria to ammonia and other nitrogenous products that cross the damaged liver–brain axis, increasing neurotoxicity and precipitating encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated systemic vascular resistance: Not a precipitant of hepatic encephalopathy; vascular resistance changes relate to hemodynamics in cirrhosis but do not directly cause encephalopathy.

 

Option B. Destruction of gut anaerobes: Usually reduces ammonia-producing flora (and is therapeutic when achieved with rifaximin), so it would not precipitate encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Thiamine pyrophosphate deficiency: Causes Wernicke encephalopathy (ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, confusion), a different syndrome without spider angiomas or asterixis and unrelated to hemoglobin accumulation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to shortness of breath, poor appetite, and abdominal distension for the past 3 months. His symptoms have progressively worsened, and he is now unable to perform his daily activities. The patient has a history of ischemic heart disease and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 5 years ago. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, abdominal distension, hepatomegaly, and bilateral lower extremity edema. A representative liver biopsy image is shown in the exhibit. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s liver findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Passive hepatic congestion

 

The clinical picture (chronic right-sided heart failure signs: JVD, hepatomegaly, ascites, peripheral edema) plus biopsy consistent with centrilobular (zone 3) congestion and sinusoidal dilatation (nutmeg liver) indicates chronic passive hepatic congestion due to congestive heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune biliary destruction: Primary biliary cholangitis shows portal-based duct injury and antimitochondrial antibodies, not centrilobular congestion.

 

Option B. Excessive deposition of iron: Hemochromatosis causes diffuse hepatocellular iron pigment and eventual micronodular cirrhosis, not the pattern of venous congestion.

 

Option C. Hepatitis virus infection: Viral hepatitis produces lobular inflammation and hepatocellular necrosis/portal interface activity rather than passive sinusoidal congestion.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with epigastric pain and positive occult blood test undergoes endoscopy, revealing hyperemic nodular mucosa. Biopsy shows submucosal glands producing alkaline mucus. Which part of the GI tract was biopsied?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First part of the duodenum

 

  • The submucosal glands producing alkaline mucus are Brunner’s glands, found only in the duodenum (especially the first part).
  • Their function is to secrete alkaline mucus that neutralizes gastric acid, protecting the duodenal mucosa and providing the right pH for pancreatic enzyme activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mid-jejunum: Jejunum has prominent plicae circulares but no submucosal glands.

 

Option C. Antrum of the stomach: Contains mucous cells in gastric pits, but not submucosal alkaline glands.

 

Option D. Terminal ileum: Contains Peyer’s patches (lymphoid tissue), not mucus-secreting submucosal glands.

 

Presence of Brunner’s glands = Duodenum (1st part).

choices.text: No recent use of nephrotoxic agent
Rise in creatinine of 0.3 mg/dl in 48 hours
50% increase in creatinine from baseline within 7 days

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the diagnostic criteria of hepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of shock

 

Diagnostic criteria of HRS require absence of shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No recent use of nephrotoxic agent: Correct. No nephrotoxic drug use is a criterion.

 

Option C. Rise in creatinine of 0.3 mg/dl in 48 hours: Yes. AKI defined by ↑ creatinine ≥0.3 mg/dl in 48h.

 

Option D. 50% increase in creatinine from baseline within 7 days: Yes. ≥50% rise in creatinine within 7 days is part of AKI definition.

 

Pathophysiology of HRS:

questions.text: Which is not used in management in Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcium citrate

 

Wilson’s disease treatment: chelators (Penicillamine, Trientine) + Zinc (↓ copper absorption). Calcium citrate is not useful.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trientine: Copper chelator.

 

Option B. Zinc: Prevents copper absorption.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Mainstay copper chelation.

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was given an antiemetic, after which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metoclopramide

 

Metoclopramide is a D2 antagonist → extrapyramidal side effects (acute dystonia, parkinsonism, tardive dyskinesia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scopolamine: Antimuscarinic, used for motion sickness, no EPS.

 

Option B. Ondansetron: 5-HT3 antagonist, safe (main chemo antiemetic).

 

Option D. Meclizine: Antihistamine, motion sickness.

questions.text: As a part of cranial nerves examination, swallowing reflex is performed on a patient. Which of the following is not involved in afferent limb of this reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facial nerve

 

Afferent limb of swallowing reflex: Glossopharyngeal (IX), Vagus (X), Trigeminal (V).

 

Facial nerve (VII) is involved in taste and salivation, not afferent limb of swallowing.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent choleretic?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bile salts

 

The most potent choleretic (stimulator of bile secretion) = bile salts (enterohepatic circulation).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic juices: Not choleretic.

 

Option C. CCK: Contracts gallbladder, but not main choleretic.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: Stimulate CCK release, but less potent than bile salts.

questions.text: A drug known to cause the following side effect is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colloidal bismuth subsalicylate

 

  • Bismuth salts (eg, colloidal bismuth subsalicylate) can cause black discoloration of the tongue and stool due to the formation of bismuth sulfide when bismuth reacts with hydrogen sulfide in saliva or gut. This pigmentation is benign and reversible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rasburicase: Used for tumor lysis syndrome (converts uric acid to allantoin); common side effects include hemolysis (in G6PD deficiency), methemoglobinemia—not pigmentation.

 

Option B. Sucralfate: A cytoprotective agent forming a physical barrier over ulcers; side effects mainly constipation, no black tongue.

 

Option D. Senna: A stimulant laxative; can cause melanosis coli (pigmentation of colonic mucosa), not tongue discoloration.

questions.text: Which of the following fluids have the highest daily secretion of potassium?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saliva

 

Saliva contains a relatively high concentration of potassium compared to other GI secretions. The daily secretion of potassium is maximal in saliva, even though the volume of secretion is smaller compared to intestinal fluids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bile: Mostly bile salts, cholesterol, bilirubin; very little potassium.

 

Option B. Jejunal secretion: Rich in bicarbonate and water, not potassium.

 

Option C. Pancreatic secretion: Mainly bicarbonate-rich fluid, low potassium.

 

NB: Rectal fluid has highest concentration of potassium.

questions.text: Which part of the GIT has the longest transit time?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colon

 

Transit time is slowest in the colon (can be 20–40 hours) due to water absorption and storage of feces before defecation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ileum: Faster than colon.

 

Option C. Stomach: Gastric emptying takes only 2–4 hours.

 

Option D. Jejunum: Transit is rapid.
